Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: JUNO: Energy-Efficient Hyper-Dense Wireless Networks with Trillions of Devices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Delivering high-speed, pervasive wireless services to trillions of mobile devices requires a significant transformation to today's wireless cellular networks. Hyper-dense heterogeneous networks (HDHNs), enabled via a viral and large-scale deployment of small cell base stations and mobile devices, are seen as one of the cornerstones of this transformation. However, most existing network design and optimization techniques fall short in handling the scale, density, sustainability, and dynamics of such HDHNs.

This project contributes to the foundations of HDHNs via innovations that include novel mobility state estimation techniques, optimized cell selection and handover methods, and a new game-theoretic framework for self-organizing resource management in energy-efficient HDHNs. The proposed approaches will be evaluated and enhanced via implementation on an experimental testbed using software radio and open source platforms.

Boosting the performance of wireless systems will have societal impacts via enablement of novel mobile services requiring high-performance network connectivity. The project results will also support the analysis of dense networks and the development of future wireless standards and products. As a new Japan-US collaboration the project will build long-term relationships between US and Japanese researchers designing sustainable, energy-efficient and dense wireless systems. The project will create new educational and outreach activities to attract under-represented minorities to the field of sustainable HDHNs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This joint US-Japan research project provided the scientific foundations needed to model, analyze, and deploy energy-efficient wireless cellular networks. In particular,  the intellectual merits included the development of innovative techniques that can be used by emerging 5G cellular networks to improve their carbon footprint and energy efficiency, while delivering high-speed wireless access. In this regard, the proposed research provided the necessary mathematical tools for designing, analyzing, and optimizing hyper-dense heterogeneous wireless networks, which will form the basis of 5G and beyond cellular systems. The developed tools have contributed to a better understanding on how such hyper-dense wireless networks can autonomously and effectively manage their energy and spectral resources, in presence of a large number of users. In addition, the developed solutions shed light on how energy harvesting base stations can be deployed and operated in hyper-dense cellular networks. The developed online optimization tools also provided the necessary frameworks needed to enable edge computing at end-user devices in tomorrow's cellular networks, thus potentially enabling a plethora of new wireless applications. Moreover, the proposed research led to advances across interdisciplinary fields that include wireless communications, game theory, network optimization, and experimental software radio development. The broader impacts included: a) Fostering a close US-Japan collaboration on research related to telecommunications and wireless systems, b) Training graduate and undergraduate students on wireless networking research, in both the US and Japan, c) Disseminating the developed innovations to the broad research community via workshops, tutorials, and online tools, and d) Outreach events to local schools that helped attract students to electrical engineering and wireless networking research.
